_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

A.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Toyota Boshoku Mississippi, LLC (TBMS) is committed to protecting facility personnel, the public, and the environment from any workplace and accidental release hazards.  An appropriate response to releases of Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) is in the written Risk Management Program.  Safety, environmental, and risk management programs are fully implemented and coordinated with community emergency responders for emergency planning and response. 



B. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The TBMS facility produces urethane molded foam seats for the automotive industry located in Mantachie, Mississippi. 



Urethane molded foam is a product made of combining chemicals that undergo a chemical reaction as they are injected into a mold cavity. One of the chemical mixtures contains approximately 65% Toluene 2, 4-Diisocyanate (TDI) and approximately 15% Toluene 2, 6-Diisocyanate (TDI). The TDI is stored in one (1) 8,000-gallon TDI Bulk Storage Tank. The 8,000-gallons of TDI equates to 65,344 pounds of TDI (max capacity). The TDI Bulk Storage Tank is located within its own building. 



The EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) is part of the Clean Air Act and applies to a process storing a specified chemical above a threshold quantity. The chemicals and threshold quantities are specified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 68. One such chemical is Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) with a threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds which is used as an ingredient in the manufacturing process. 



After reviewing the facility operations and the RMP regulations, it was determined that the entire facility is considered one process.  Based on the facility processes and applicable regulations, it was determined that the facility is subject to Program 2 of the RMP regulations.



TBMS is committed to protecting facility personnel, the public, and the environment from any workplace a

nd accidental release hazards.  An appropriate response to releases of TDI is in the written Risk Management Program. Safety, environmental, and risk management programs are fully implemented and coordinated with community emergency responders for emergency planning and response. TBMS's specific prevention steps include:

1. Hazard reviews to identify, evaluate and control potential TDI process hazards,

2. Develop, review and update operating and maintenance procedures for the TDI process,

3. Provide the appropriate training for TDI process operators, maintenance personnel, and   

   emergency response personnel.

4. Conduct timely investigations of all incidents involving the TDI process.

5. Conduct RMP Compliance audits as per RMP regulations.



C. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Process Safety Information: TBMS has completed a compilation of written safety information to be used in conducting the Hazard Review. The Hazard Review has been conducted using the process safety information gathered in order to identify and understand the hazards posed by the TDI System. 



Hazard Review: TBMS has updated and revalidate the Hazard Review as necessary and at least every five (5) years. The Hazard Review was conducted using  the "What IF" methodology, which is one of the methodologies specified in 40 CFR 68.67, and was performed by a team with expertise in engineering and process operations, including one member who has expertise in the TDI System and a member knowledgeable in the specified  methodology. A system was established to promptly address the team's findings and recommendations; assure that the recommendations are resolved in a timely manner and that the resolution is documented; develop a written schedule of when these actions are to be completed; and communicate the actions to operation, maintenance and other employees who may be affected by the recommendations or actions.



Operating Procedures: TBM

S has developed written operating procedures to provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities at each operation where TDI is utilized. These written operating procedures will be consistent with the process safety information for each operating phase, operating limitations, safety and health considerations, safety systems and their functions. The operating procedures will be readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the TDI system. These operating procedures will be reviewed as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice. TBMS will develop and implement safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout; opening process equipment or piping; and control entrance into the TDI storage area.



Training: TBMS has provided training for each employee associated with the TDI system. This training includes an overview of the process and operating procedures as outlined in 40 CFR 68.67.  Refresher training is provided every three (3) years or more often as necessary. TBMS documents and maintains records of employee training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.



Mechanical Integrity: TBMS has developed a written preventive maintenance program to maintain the on-going integrity of the equipment used in the TDI process (i.e., storage tanks, pumps, piping systems, etc); additionally, inspections, testing, equipment deficiencies, and quality assurance are addressed.

Each person who has responsibilities to perform maintenance on the TDI system components receives training at least every three (3) years or more often if necessary.



Compliance Audits: TBMS has and will certify that they have evaluated compliance with the provisions of 40 CFR, Part 68 every three (3) years. The compliance audit will be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the TDI system.  A report of the findings of the audit will be developed.  TBMS will promp

tly determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and document that deficiencies have been corrected.  Records of the two (2) most recent compliance audit reports will be maintained. The last audit was conduct on April 7, 2016.



Incident Investigation: TBMS will investigate each incident, which results in or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of TDI. Incident investigations will be initiated as promptly as possible, but no later than 48 hours following the incident. The incident investigation team will consist of at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved, including contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor. A report will be prepared at the conclusion of the investigation, and TBMS will promptly address and resolve the incident findings and recommendations. Resolutions and corrective actions will be documented. Incident investigation reports will be retained for five (5) years.



D. Five-year Accident History

TBMS has not had an accidental release of TDI that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite or any known off-site, death, injuries evacuations, sheltering in place, property, property damage, or environmental damage in the past five (5) years. 



E. Emergency Response Program

TBMS has developed and implemented an emergency response program for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment. This program will include the following elements: 

1.  An emergency management plan, which is maintained on site and contains at least the following elements:



a. Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies;

b. Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary for accidental exposures; and

c. Procedures for emergency response after an accidental release of TDI.



2. Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection.



3. Training for all

employees in relevant procedures; 



4. Select personnel are provided 24-HR HAZWOPER training with annual 8-HR refresher; and



5. Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency management plan to reflect changes at TBMS and ensure that employees are informed of changes.



F. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

In an attempt to insure a continual improvement in the facility worker protection and release prevention programs, training is being conducted annually on this program.  This program requires the attendance of all personnel whose job is related to the TDI system.  Additionally, audits will be performed as specified in the RMP plan, which requires TBMS to assess areas of the RMP plan that may need to be changed or improved.
